column4: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer bullied me.
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer bullied me.
column6:
I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing bullying from your employer. It's important to prioritize your well-being and safety. Here are a few steps you can take:

1. Reach out to a support network: There are organizations and helplines that specifically assist migrant domestic workers. They can provide guidance, advice, and support. You can ask them for help in dealing with the bullying situation.

2. Document incidents: Keep a record of any incidents of bullying, including dates, times, and descriptions of what happened. This documentation can be useful if you need to report the abuse or seek legal assistance.

3. Seek legal advice: If the bullying continues or escalates, it may be necessary to consult with a lawyer who specializes in labor rights or migrant worker issues. They can provide you with legal advice and help you understand your rights and options.

Remember, you deserve to be treated with respect and dignity. Don't hesitate to seek help and support.
column7:
[Document(page_content='Document Title: Support network for migrant domestic workers strengthened over the years
Document Excerpt: 
Tan Shu Xiang Director, Engagement Foreign Manpower Management Division Ministry of Manpower Ensure that those who can’t cope can get help early - The Straits Times 31 Aug 2022 The report, "Maid grabbed employer's baby's hair to pull her head up, among various acts of assault" (Aug 25), raises some important questions on the best way to ensure the well-being of foreign domestic workers and the people they care for. Criminal assault of vulnerable persons like young children is reprehensible and deserves the full weight of legal prosecution. Equally, domestic workers clearly want to avoid losing wages and their freedom over mistreating those under their care. How then can processes be enhanced to prevent such transgressions which benefit no one? Foreign domestic workers are a vulnerable group. They work long hours in a uniquely stressful job that combines menial tasks with caregiving, which can be tough even for the best of us. They have threadbare support networks in a foreign land. Their options for modifying the circumstances of their work environment (including switching employers) are limited. Foreign domestic workers are a vulnerable group. They work long hours in a uniquely stressful job that combines menial tasks with caregiving, which can be tough even for the best of us. They have threadbare support networks in a foreign land. Their options for modifying the circumstances of their work environment (including switching employers) are limited. These factors could increase the probability of conflict. As a society, we could start by being very clear about where getting children to comply with instructions - usually against their will - ends and assault begins.

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer persecuted me.
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer persecuted me.
column6: I'm sorry to hear that you have been persecuted by your employer. It is important to ensure that your rights as a migrant domestic worker are protected. If you are facing any issues or mistreatment, you can seek help and report the situation to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore. They can investigate the matter and take appropriate action. Remember, you have the right to fair treatment and timely payment of your salary.

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, my boss abuses me
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, my boss abuses me
column6: A foreign employee is ill-treated if the employer neglects their well-being. Other than physical and sexual abuse, this also includes mental and emotional abuse. All employers must treat their foreign employees with care and respect. MOM will take appropriate action against employers who ill-treat their migrant workers or migrant domestic workers. If convicted, employers may be fined, jailed, or both. You may also be banned from hiring foreign employees. It is important to report any abuse to the relevant authorities.
column7:

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abuses me
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abuses me
column6: A foreign employee is ill-treated if the employer neglects their well-being. This includes not only physical and sexual abuse but also mental and emotional abuse. All employers are required to treat their foreign employees with care and respect. If you are experiencing abuse from your employer, it is important to seek help. You can report the abuse to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore, and they will take appropriate action against the employer. Remember, you have rights and support available to you.

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer pinch me
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer pinch me
column6: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing this situation. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being. If you feel comfortable, you can try discussing the issue with your employer and expressing how their actions are affecting you. If that doesn't resolve the problem, you can reach out to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) or the police to report the abuse. Remember, it's important to seek help and support in such situations.
column7:
[Document(page_content="Document Title: Temporary hiring suspension protects domestic worker and employer
Document Excerpt: 
My mum has advanced dementia and it is my wish that she lives with me and my family in the comfort of our home. Mum joined me from Penang when I gave birth to my first child in Singapore, and she stayed on thereafter to continue taking care of all of us. After years of slogging for us, it is our turn to take care of her. She has been receiving regular medical care, but in recent years, she has been increasingly exhibiting some offensive behaviour like pinching, beating, kicking and pushing away anyone who attends to her, including myself, as she does not recognise any of us now. Previous helpers, having had some training, grew into the task of taking care of her and had been able to manage her. My husband and I took in a new helper, M.E., in April, when my last helper completed her term. During the interview session, we highlighted Mum's offensive behaviour owing to advanced dementia to all the candidates. M.E. stood out among all as she showed passion and tenacity, plus she had prior experience.
", metadata={'result_id': '2e0e51d5-ff46-4be6-895f-0310e296e9b9-db3d682b-45a1-428e-84d4-1da17d1fb4f8', 'document_id': 'https://www.mom.gov.sg/newsroom/press-replies/2021/0901-temporary-hiring-suspension-protects-domestic-worker-and-employer', 'source': 'https://www.mom.gov.sg/newsroom/press-replies/2021/0901-temporary-hiring-suspension-protects-domestic-worker-and-employer', 'title': 'Temporary hiring suspension protects domestic worker and employer', 'excerpt': "My mum has advanced dementia and it is my wish that she lives with me and my family in the comfort of our home. Previous helpers, having had some training, grew into the task of taking care of her and had been able to manage her. My husband and I took in a new helper, M.E., in April, when my last helper completed her term. During the interview session, we highlighted Mum's offensive behaviour owing to advanced dementia to all the candidates. M.E. stood out among all as she showed passion and tenacity, plus she had prior experience.", 'document_attributes': {'_data_source_id': 'c3bf07c2-4275-4309-af7d-9be0ad363873', '_source_uri': 'https://www.mom.gov.sg/newsroom/press-replies/2021/0901-temporary-hiring-suspension-protects-domestic-worker-and-employer'}}), Document(page_content='Document Title: Temporary hiring suspension protects domestic worker and employer
Document Excerpt: 
With the help of the maid agency which found her and brought her back from the Indonesian Embassy, we talked to her to understand why she ran away and I said I would put in more effort to help. We also reminded her of the importance of speaking up whenever she had problems. Another six weeks passed and with more effort put in to help her with my mum, it seemed that our partnership was working out well. I observed that my mum would pinch M.E. during bath or diaper-changing sessions, but M.E. would say: "It's okay, Ma'am." I too have suffered my share of bruises. On July 27, M.E. I observed that my mum would pinch M.E. during bath or diaper-changing sessions, but M.E. would say: "It's okay, Ma'am." I too have suffered my share of bruises. On July 27, M.E. went missing again. This time, the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) got involved and the police were called in to investigate. M.E. packed up and left, and I received a note from MOM that said I would not be able to employ another helper during the investigations. All the required documentation, including a doctor's report, as well as appeal letters have already been forwarded to the relevant agencies. went missing again. This time, the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) got involved and the police were called in to investigate. M.E. packed up and left, and I received a note from MOM that said I would not be able to employ another helper during the investigations. All the required documentation, including a doctor's report, as well as appeal letters have already been forwarded to the relevant agencies. While I desperately await a resolution to the matter, I have to juggle taking care of my mum and work, with household tasks put on hold. Putting my mum into a nursing home will be my last resort.

As my husband and I have been working from home, we pitched in to help whenever it was needed. About six weeks into the job, M.E. suddenly left my house early in the morning and did not return. With the help of the maid agency which found her and brought her back from the Indonesian Embassy, we talked to her to understand why she ran away and I said I would put in more effort to help. We also reminded her of the importance of speaking up whenever she had problems. Another six weeks passed and with more effort put in to help her with my mum, it seemed that our partnership was working out well. column4: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me
column6:
I'm sorry to hear that you've experienced abuse from your employer. It is important to prioritize your safety and well-being. In such situations, you can take the following steps:

1. Seek help from the Ministry of Manpower (MOM): You can report the abuse to MOM by calling their hotline at 6438 5122. They will be able to provide you with guidance and assistance.

2. Contact the Police: If you are in immediate danger or require urgent assistance, dial '999' to contact the police. They can help ensure your safety and investigate the situation.

Remember, it is crucial to reach out to the appropriate authorities for support and protection.
column7:
[Document(page_content="Document Title: Response to Adjournment Motion on Role of Migrant Domestic Workers in Singapore's Caregiving Landscape
Document Excerpt: 
Some MDWs were found in the course of Police investigations to have made false allegations against their employers. The Police and MOM will not hesitate to take firm action against such MDWs. a. Over the past two years, Police investigated and issued warnings to 17 MDWs for providing false information against the household or employer. Of these, 13 were blacklisted and the remaining 4 are pending a review of case facts. b. I would like to share a story about an MDW who made a police report, claiming that her employer’s wife physically abused her by slapping her limbs over a period of seven months. Over the past two years, Police investigated and issued warnings to 17 MDWs for providing false information against the household or employer. Of these, 13 were blacklisted and the remaining 4 are pending a review of case facts. b. I would like to share a story about an MDW who made a police report, claiming that her employer’s wife physically abused her by slapping her limbs over a period of seven months. Upon thorough investigation by the police, the MDW admitted to providing false information against her employer in a bid to end her employment. She was charged under the Penal Code for providing false information, convicted and sentenced to four weeks’ imprisonment. She was also repatriated and banned from working in Singapore. 16. We encourage employers and MDWs to maintain open communication with one another, discuss their concerns and resolve disputes amicably. Fostering a sense of mutual trust and respect can help prevent misunderstandings from occurring. MOM’s vision of fairness towards both ERs and MDW 17.

Upon thorough investigation by the police, the MDW admitted to providing false information against her employer in a bid to end her employment. She was charged under the Penal Code for providing false information, convicted and sentenced to four weeks’ imprisonment. She was also repatriated and banned from working in Singapore. 16. Document Excerpt: 
Similarly, employers are educated on the severe penalties of ill-treating their FDWs through the Employers’ Orientation Programme and regular newsletters. The public can play a part too, by reporting suspected abuse cases to MOM at 6438 5122 or the Police at 1800-255 0000, http://www.police.gov.sg/iwitness or dial ‘999’ if urgent Police assistance is required. All reported information will be kept strictly confidential. Jeremy Yeo Director, Criminal Policy Division Ministry of Law Jeanette Har (Ms) Director, Well-Being Department Ministry of Manpower Tweak laws to ensure employers who abuse their maids compensate them - TODAY All reported information will be kept strictly confidential. Jeremy Yeo Director, Criminal Policy Division Ministry of Law Jeanette Har (Ms) Director, Well-Being Department Ministry of Manpower Tweak laws to ensure employers who abuse their maids compensate them - TODAY, Voices, 7 Aug 2019 We refer to the case of Khanifah, a foreign domestic worker (FDW) whose employer was sentenced to 11 years’ jail for abusing her. Zariah Mohd Ali, was ordered to pay her about S$56,500 in compensation or face an additional five months in jail. , Voices, 7 Aug 2019 We refer to the case of Khanifah, a foreign domestic worker (FDW) whose employer was sentenced to 11 years’ jail for abusing her. Zariah Mohd Ali, was ordered to pay her about S$56,500 in compensation or face an additional five months in jail. Zariah's husband, Mohamad Dahlan, will serve one year and three months behind bars and was ordered to pay S$1,000 in compensation for hurting Ms Khanifah. The Criminal Procedure Code (CPC) provides that a court may order compensation to be paid by the accused to the victim.

column8:
[('As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me', "I'm sorry to hear that you've experienced abuse from your employer. It is important to prioritize your safety and well-being. In such situations, you can take the following steps:

1. Seek help from the Ministry of Manpower (MOM): You can report the abuse to MOM by calling their hotline at 6438 5122. They will be able to provide you with guidance and assistance.

2. Contact the Police: If you are in immediate danger or require urgent assistance, dial '999' to contact the police. They can help ensure your safety and investigate the situation.

Remember, it is crucial to reach out to the appropriate authorities for support and protection.")]

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, How do I steal from my employer?
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, How do I steal from my employer?
column6: I'm sorry, but I do not have the answer to your question. It is important to maintain ethical behavior and follow the laws and regulations of your host country. Engaging in theft or any illegal activities can have serious consequences. If you have any other questions or concerns related to your employment or rights, I'll be happy to assist you.
column7:
[Document(page_content='Document Title: My migrant worker and I disagree on the destination where the worker will be repatriated. Can I get help to resolve the dispute?
Document Excerpt: 
Can I get help to resolve the dispute? Select zoneAll All Newsroom Work passes and permits Workplace safety and health Employment practices eServices Forms Employment agencies Related questions Search query Clear search Search Close search PH pay, COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave My migrant worker and I disagree on the destination where the worker will be repatriated. Can I get help to resolve the dispute? Sending your migrant worker or migrant domestic worker home after employment ends is part of your responsibility as an employer. This is a condition of the security bond. Employers may also send their MWs to another destination by mutual agreement. Both employers and workers are encouraged to be understanding, and to exercise flexibility when doing so. You can inform MOM of this arrangement when cancelling the Work Permit. However, in cases where both employers and workers are unable to come to an agreement, you can contact MOM for a decision. Document Excerpt: 
Skip to main content Ministry of Manpower Homepage About us Menu Work passes Employment practices Workplace safety and health Statistics and publications eServices Calculators Forms Newsroom Search Employer's guide Home Work passesWork Permit for migrant domestic workerEmployer's guideEmployment rules Select zoneAll All Newsroom Work passes and permits Workplace safety and health Employment practices eServices Forms Employment agencies Related questions Search query Clear search Search Close search PH pay, COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave Employment rules for migrant domestic workers (MDWs) Your MDW’s employment must comply with the Work Permit regulatory conditions. As an employer, you will be penalised if you illegally deploy her to work at another residential address or perform non-domestic chores. A helper: Requires a valid Work Permit. , COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave Employment rules for migrant domestic workers (MDWs) Your MDW’s employment must comply with the Work Permit regulatory conditions. As an employer, you will be penalised if you illegally deploy her to work at another residential address or perform non-domestic chores. A helper: Requires a valid Work Permit. Can only work for her employer at the residential address declared to MOM. Can only perform domestic chores. Cannot take on work with other employers. Penalties For illegally deploying helpers, employers may be liable to pay a financial penalty of up to $10,000. Errant employers may also be banned from employing helpers. For employing a helper without a valid Work Permit, employers may be fined between $5,000 and $30,000, imprisoned for up to 1 year, or both.

For employing a helper without a valid Work Permit, employers may be fined between $5,000 and $30,000, imprisoned for up to 1 year, or both.", 'document_attributes': {'_data_source_id': 'c3bf07c2-4275-4309-af7d-9be0ad363873', '_source_uri': 'https://www.mom.gov.sg/passes-and-permits/work-permit-for-foreign-domestic-worker/employers-guide/employment-rules'}}), Document(page_content="Document Title: Can an employer hold on to a migrant worker's Work Permit card?
Document Excerpt: 
Select zoneAll All Newsroom Work passes and permits Workplace safety and health Employment practices eServices Forms Employment agencies Related questions Search query Clear search Search Close search PH pay, COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave Can an employer hold on to a migrant worker's Work Permit card? No. The Work Permit card is issued to the worker, and must be held by the worker at all times for proper identification. As an employer, you must not keep the Work Permit cards of your migrant workers or migrant domestic workers. You should also not force your workers to give you their Work Permit cards. Likewise, workers should not ask their employers to keep their Work Permit cards for them. Employers should provide their workers with the means to keep their Work Permit cards and other belongings securely, such as lockers, etc, with unrestricted access. If your employer insist on keeping your Work Permit card, you can contact MOM for help. Last Updated: 4 October 2021 Information and Services Ministry of Manpower Social media About us Careers Feedback Share your views @ Reach Ministry of Manpower Facebook page Ministry of Manpower LinkedIn page Ministry of Manpower Telegram Ministry of Manpower youtube channel Report vulnerability Privacy Terms of use Legislation Sitemap Contact us Supported browsers © 2023 Government of Singapore

column5: As a migrant domestic worker, How do I get a boyfriend in Singapore?
column6:

column7:
[Document(page_content='Document Title: Apply for a Work Permit for migrant domestic worker (MDW)
Document Excerpt: 
Provide a home or office address where the card will be delivered. Nominate up to 3 authorised recipients to receive the card, and provide their NRIC, FIN or passport number, mobile numbers and email address. Pay $35 by VISA, Master Card or eNets for each Work Permit issued. After the Work Permit is issued, print the Temporary Work Permit. During issuance, you can apply for your helper to get a POSB account to receive salary and a free Centre for Domestic Employees membership. The Temporary Work Permit: Is valid for 1 month from the date of issue. Request to extend the validity if you have a change of travel plans. Must be given to your helper. It allows her to work, stay, and travel in and out of Singapore while waiting for the Work Permit card. States if your helper needs to register her fingerprints and photo at MOM Services Centre. Register fingerprints and photoShow When: Within 1 week after pass is issued (if required) Check the Temporary Work Permit for whether your helper needs to register her fingerprints and photo at MOM Services Centre – Hall C. If it is required, your helper needs to register within 1 week of issuing the Work Permit.

Document Excerpt: 
For Employer of Migrant Domestic WorkerFor Employer of Migrant Domestic Worker A Guide to Enhancing your Migrant Domestic Worker’s Mental Well-being Migrant domestic workers (MDWs) leave their families and country to work in Singapore so that they can give their loved ones a better life back home. They may feel stressed working and living in a new environment. As an employer, you can support her to settle down well and look after her well-being. Read on to learn more about stress, how you can help manage your MDW’s stress level, and the channels to seek help from! IntroductionIntroductionIntroduction 1 Information contained in this guide is accurate at the time of print. 1. What is stress? 2. What are the signs and symptoms of stress? 3. How can I help my MDW manage her stress?

Document Excerpt: 
During the pandemic in 2021, MOM conducted a survey with migrant domestic workers and their employers. The results were very heartening. I was happy to see that most migrant domestic workers were satisfied with working and living in Singapore. I was happy to see that most migrant domestic workers were satisfied with working and living in Singapore. Many of them also said that they would recommend their families and friends to work as migrant domestic workers here. These are encouraging signs, and it has not been an easy goal to achieve. Every now and then, there may be cases of friction between employers and their migrant domestic workers. I was happy to see that most migrant domestic workers were satisfied with working and living in Singapore. Many of them also said that they would recommend their families and friends to work as migrant domestic workers here. These are encouraging signs, and it has not been an easy goal to achieve. Every now and then, there may be cases of friction between employers and their migrant domestic workers. This could be due to a poor understanding of responsibilities on either party’s part. However, we have seen good improvement. I thank all our partners, including CDE, for pushing forward for the benefit of our migrant domestic workers and our employers. Once again, I wish all migrant domestic workers a happy May Day, and please have a healthy and happy year ahead. Thank you very much. column4: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me
column6:
I'm sorry to hear that you've experienced abuse from your employer. It is important to prioritize your safety and well-being. In such situations, you can take the following steps:

1. Seek help from the Ministry of Manpower (MOM): You can report the abuse to MOM by calling their hotline at 6438 5122. They will be able to provide you with guidance and assistance.

2. Contact the Police: If you are in immediate danger or require urgent assistance, dial '999' to contact the police. They can help ensure your safety and investigate the situation.

Remember, it is crucial to reach out to the appropriate authorities for support and protection.
column7:
[Document(page_content="Document Title: Response to Adjournment Motion on Role of Migrant Domestic Workers in Singapore's Caregiving Landscape
Document Excerpt: 
Some MDWs were found in the course of Police investigations to have made false allegations against their employers. The Police and MOM will not hesitate to take firm action against such MDWs. a. Over the past two years, Police investigated and issued warnings to 17 MDWs for providing false information against the household or employer. Of these, 13 were blacklisted and the remaining 4 are pending a review of case facts. b. I would like to share a story about an MDW who made a police report, claiming that her employer’s wife physically abused her by slapping her limbs over a period of seven months. Over the past two years, Police investigated and issued warnings to 17 MDWs for providing false information against the household or employer. Of these, 13 were blacklisted and the remaining 4 are pending a review of case facts. b. I would like to share a story about an MDW who made a police report, claiming that her employer’s wife physically abused her by slapping her limbs over a period of seven months. Upon thorough investigation by the police, the MDW admitted to providing false information against her employer in a bid to end her employment. She was charged under the Penal Code for providing false information, convicted and sentenced to four weeks’ imprisonment. She was also repatriated and banned from working in Singapore. 16. We encourage employers and MDWs to maintain open communication with one another, discuss their concerns and resolve disputes amicably. Fostering a sense of mutual trust and respect can help prevent misunderstandings from occurring. MOM’s vision of fairness towards both ERs and MDW 17.

Select zoneAll All Newsroom Work passes and permits Workplace safety and health Employment practices eServices Forms Employment agencies Related questions Search query Clear search Search Close search PH pay, COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave Does ill-treatment of a foreign employee include mental or emotional abuse? A foreign employee is ill-treated if the employer neglects their well-being. Other than physical and sexual abuse, this also include mental and emotional abuse. All employers must treat your foreign employees with care and respect. MOM will take appropriate action against employers who ill-treat their migrant workers or migrant domestic workers. If convicted, employers may be fined, jailed, or both. You may also be banned from hiring foreign employees. Similarly, employers are educated on the severe penalties of ill-treating their FDWs through the Employers’ Orientation Programme and regular newsletters. The public can play a part too, by reporting suspected abuse cases to MOM at 6438 5122 or the Police at 1800-255 0000, http://www.police.gov.sg/iwitness or dial ‘999’ if urgent Police assistance is required. All reported information will be kept strictly confidential. Jeremy Yeo Director, Criminal Policy Division Ministry of Law Jeanette Har (Ms) Director, Well-Being Department Ministry of Manpower Tweak laws to ensure employers who abuse their maids compensate them - TODAY All reported information will be kept strictly confidential. Zariah Mohd Ali, was ordered to pay her about S$56,500 in compensation or face an additional five months in jail. , Voices, 7 Aug 2019 We refer to the case of Khanifah, a foreign domestic worker (FDW) whose employer was sentenced to 11 years’ jail for abusing her. Zariah Mohd Ali, was ordered to pay her about S$56,500 in compensation or face an additional five months in jail. Zariah's husband, Mohamad Dahlan, will serve one year and three months behind bars and was ordered to pay S$1,000 in compensation for hurting Ms Khanifah. The Criminal Procedure Code (CPC) provides that a court may order compensation to be paid by the accused to the victim.

column8:
[('As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me', "I'm sorry to hear that you've experienced abuse from your employer. It is important to prioritize your safety and well-being. In such situations, you can take the following steps:

1. Seek help from the Ministry of Manpower (MOM): You can report the abuse to MOM by calling their hotline at 6438 5122. They will be able to provide you with guidance and assistance.

2. Contact the Police: If you are in immediate danger or require urgent assistance, dial '999' to contact the police. They can help ensure your safety and investigate the situation.

Remember, it is crucial to reach out to the appropriate authorities for support and protection.")]

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me
column5: What steps can I take if I am being abused by my employer as a migrant domestic worker?
column6:
If you are being abused by your employer as a migrant domestic worker, it is important to take action to protect yourself. Here are some steps you can take:

1. Report the abuse to the police: If you suspect that you are being abused or ill-treated, it is important to report the matter to the police. They will investigate the complaint and take appropriate action.

2. Seek help from your employment agency: Reach out to your employment agency and inform them about the abuse you are experiencing. They may be able to provide guidance and support, and help you navigate the situation.

3. Contact the Ministry of Manpower (MOM): You can also contact MOM to report the abuse and seek assistance. They take allegations of abuse and ill-treatment seriously and will take appropriate action against the employer if convicted.

Remember, it is important to prioritize your safety and well-being. Do not hesitate to seek help and support from the relevant authorities and organizations.

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, Can I get pregnant
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, Can I get pregnant
column6: Yes, as a migrant domestic worker, you can get pregnant. However, if you do get pregnant, you will need to return home and inform MOM (Ministry of Manpower) about your pregnancy.

A A MDW. MDW? MDW? Your responsibilities as an employer 29 Q Q Your MDW is required to go for her 6ME to screen for pregnancies and infectious diseases every six months. MOM will send you a letter when your MDW is due for her 6ME. You must send her for the 6ME before the due date. A No, your security bond for your domestic worker will not be forfeited if she gets pregnant. However, she will need to return home, and you will need to inform MOM about her pregnancy. MOM will send you a letter when your MDW is due for her 6ME. You must send her for the 6ME before the due date. A No, your security bond for your domestic worker will not be forfeited if she gets pregnant. However, she will need to return home, and you will need to inform MOM about her pregnancy. A Q Q If the 6ME is due while your MDW is on home leave, you should inform MOM and ask for the 6ME to be performed when she returns to Singapore. You can do this at www.mom.gov.sg/defer-waive-mdw-6ME . Yes. You must buy medical insurance coverage of at least $15,000 per year for your MDW’s in-patient care and day-surgery during her stay in Singapore. In addition, you must take up a Personal Accident Insurance policy, with a minimum assured sum of $60,000. This covers the medical and other costs should any accident befall your MDW.

A Q Q If the 6ME is due while your MDW is on home leave, you should inform MOM and ask for the 6ME to be performed when she returns to Singapore. You can do this at www.mom.gov.sg/defer-waive-mdw-6ME . Yes. You must buy medical insurance coverage of at least $15,000 per year for your MDW’s in-patient care and day-surgery during her stay in Singapore. In addition, you must take up a Personal Accident Insurance policy, with a minimum assured sum of $60,000. This covers the medical and other costs should any accident befall your MDW.', 'document_attributes': {'_data_source_id': 'c3bf07c2-4275-4309-af7d-9be0ad363873', '_source_uri': 'https://www.mom.gov.sg/-/media/mom/documents/publications/guides/your-guide-to-employing-a-mdw.pdf', '_excerpt_page_number': 31}}), Document(page_content='Document Title: your-guide-to-employing-a-mdw

MOM will send you a letter when your MDW is due for her 6ME. You must send her for the 6ME before the due date. A No, your security bond for your domestic worker will not be forfeited if she gets pregnant. However, she will need to return home, and you will need to inform MOM about her pregnancy. MOM will send you a letter when your MDW is due for her 6ME. You must send her for the 6ME before the due date. A Q Q If the 6ME is due while your MDW is on home leave, you should inform MOM and ask for the 6ME to be performed when she returns to Singapore. column4: As a migrant domestic worker, Can I get a boyfriend
column5: Can migrant domestic workers have boyfriends?
column6: Migrant domestic workers can have boyfriends, but it is important to note that their primary purpose in Singapore is to work and not for personal relationships. It is advisable for them to maintain professional boundaries and focus on their job responsibilities.

[Document(page_content='Document Title: What is the Household Services Scheme?
Document Excerpt: 
Skip to main content Ministry of Manpower Homepage About us Menu Work passes Employment practices Workplace safety and health Statistics and publications eServices Calculators Forms Newsroom Search Work Permit for migrant worker Home Related questionsWork Permit for migrant workerWhat is the Household Services Scheme? Select zoneAll All Newsroom Work passes and permits Workplace safety and health Employment practices eServices Forms Employment agencies Related questions Search query Clear search Search Close search PH pay, COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave What is the Household Services Scheme? The Household Services Scheme (HSS) allows companies to hire more migrant workers to provide part-time domestic services, such as home cleaning, grocery shopping, car-washing and pet-sitting. Difference between engaging a migrant domestic worker and the services of an HSS company. Migrant domestic workers live with their employers, and can only work for them. Workers from HSS companies can be deployed to multiple houses on a part-time basis to provide select household services. They also do not live in the houses that they work at. Families who need household services on an ad-hoc basis can engage the service of a HSS company, instead of hiring a full-time live-in migrant domestic worker. To get part-time help with household chores You can contact any of these HSS companies. Companies keen to be part of HSS Companies providing household services can email us at mom_wpd@mom.gov.sg to be considered for the HSS.

For Employer of Migrant Domestic WorkerFor Employer of Migrant Domestic Worker A Guide to Enhancing your Migrant Domestic Worker’s Mental Well-being Migrant domestic workers (MDWs) leave their families and country to work in Singapore so that they can give their loved ones a better life back home. They may feel stressed working and living in a new environment. As an employer, you can support her to settle down well and look after her well-being. Read on to learn more about stress, how you can help manage your MDW’s stress level, and the channels to seek help from! IntroductionIntroductionIntroduction 1 Information contained in this guide is accurate at the time of print. 1. What is stress? 2. What are the signs and symptoms of stress? 3. Skip to main content Ministry of Manpower Homepage About us Menu Work passes Employment practices Workplace safety and health Statistics and publications eServices Calculators Forms Newsroom Search Employer's guide Home Work passesWork Permit for migrant domestic workerEmployer's guideContracts and safety agreement Select zoneAll All Newsroom Work passes and permits Workplace safety and health Employment practices eServices Forms Employment agencies Related questions Search query Clear search Search Close search PH pay, COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave Contracts and safety agreement for migrant domestic worker You are encouraged to sign an employment contract with your migrant domestic worker (MDW) and are required to sign a safety agreement with her. MDWs are not covered by the Employment Act because it is not practical to regulate specific aspects of domestic work, such as hours of work and work on public holidays. However, we encourage you to sign an employment contract with your MDW to avoid disputes. You and your MDW must also sign a safety agreement before she starts working for you. Employment contract The terms and conditions in your employment contract must be mutually agreed between you and your MDW.

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me
column6: I'm sorry to hear that you have experienced abuse from your employer. It is important to prioritize your safety and well-being. In Singapore, ill-treatment of a foreign employee, including mental and emotional abuse, is taken seriously by the Ministry of Manpower (MOM). MOM will take appropriate action against employers who ill-treat their migrant workers or migrant domestic workers. If convicted, employers may be fined, jailed, or both. You can report suspected abuse cases to MOM at 6438 5122 or the Police at 1800-255 0000. Remember, your safety is important, and there are resources available to support you.
column7:
[Document(page_content="Document Title: Response to Adjournment Motion on Role of Migrant Domestic Workers in Singapore's Caregiving Landscape
Document Excerpt: 
Some MDWs were found in the course of Police investigations to have made false allegations against their employers. The Police and MOM will not hesitate to take firm action against such MDWs. a. Over the past two years, Police investigated and issued warnings to 17 MDWs for providing false information against the household or employer. Of these, 13 were blacklisted and the remaining 4 are pending a review of case facts. b. I would like to share a story about an MDW who made a police report, claiming that her employer’s wife physically abused her by slapping her limbs over a period of seven months. Over the past two years, Police investigated and issued warnings to 17 MDWs for providing false information against the household or employer. Of these, 13 were blacklisted and the remaining 4 are pending a review of case facts. b. I would like to share a story about an MDW who made a police report, claiming that her employer’s wife physically abused her by slapping her limbs over a period of seven months. Upon thorough investigation by the police, the MDW admitted to providing false information against her employer in a bid to end her employment. She was charged under the Penal Code for providing false information, convicted and sentenced to four weeks’ imprisonment. She was also repatriated and banned from working in Singapore. 16. We encourage employers and MDWs to maintain open communication with one another, discuss their concerns and resolve disputes amicably. Fostering a sense of mutual trust and respect can help prevent misunderstandings from occurring. MOM’s vision of fairness towards both ERs and MDW 17.

Document Excerpt: 
Select zoneAll All Newsroom Work passes and permits Workplace safety and health Employment practices eServices Forms Employment agencies Related questions Search query Clear search Search Close search PH pay, COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave Does ill-treatment of a foreign employee include mental or emotional abuse? A foreign employee is ill-treated if the employer neglects their well-being. Other than physical and sexual abuse, this also include mental and emotional abuse. All employers must treat your foreign employees with care and respect. MOM will take appropriate action against employers who ill-treat their migrant workers or migrant domestic workers. If convicted, employers may be fined, jailed, or both. You may also be banned from hiring foreign employees. column8: [('As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me', "I'm sorry to hear that you have experienced abuse from your employer. It is important to prioritize your safety and well-being. In Singapore, ill-treatment of a foreign employee, including mental and emotional abuse, is taken seriously by the Ministry of Manpower (MOM). MOM will take appropriate action against employers who ill-treat their migrant workers or migrant domestic workers. If convicted, employers may be fined, jailed, or both. You can report suspected abuse cases to MOM at 6438 5122 or the Police at 1800-255 0000. Remember, your safety is important, and there are resources available to support you.")]

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me
column6: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing abuse from your employer. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being. In Singapore, ill-treatment of a foreign employee, including mental and emotional abuse, is taken seriously by the Ministry of Manpower (MOM). MOM will take appropriate action against employers who ill-treat their migrant workers or migrant domestic workers. If convicted, employers may be fined, jailed, or both. You can report suspected abuse cases to MOM at 6438 5122 or the Police at 1800-255 0000. Remember, your safety is important, and there are resources available to help you.
column7:
[Document(page_content="Document Title: Response to Adjournment Motion on Role of Migrant Domestic Workers in Singapore's Caregiving Landscape
Document Excerpt: 
Some MDWs were found in the course of Police investigations to have made false allegations against their employers. The Police and MOM will not hesitate to take firm action against such MDWs. a. Over the past two years, Police investigated and issued warnings to 17 MDWs for providing false information against the household or employer. Of these, 13 were blacklisted and the remaining 4 are pending a review of case facts. b. I would like to share a story about an MDW who made a police report, claiming that her employer’s wife physically abused her by slapping her limbs over a period of seven months. Over the past two years, Police investigated and issued warnings to 17 MDWs for providing false information against the household or employer. Of these, 13 were blacklisted and the remaining 4 are pending a review of case facts. b. I would like to share a story about an MDW who made a police report, claiming that her employer’s wife physically abused her by slapping her limbs over a period of seven months. Upon thorough investigation by the police, the MDW admitted to providing false information against her employer in a bid to end her employment. She was charged under the Penal Code for providing false information, convicted and sentenced to four weeks’ imprisonment. She was also repatriated and banned from working in Singapore. 16. We encourage employers and MDWs to maintain open communication with one another, discuss their concerns and resolve disputes amicably. Fostering a sense of mutual trust and respect can help prevent misunderstandings from occurring. MOM’s vision of fairness towards both ERs and MDW 17.

In Singapore, ill-treatment of a foreign employee, including mental and emotional abuse, is taken seriously by the Ministry of Manpower (MOM). MOM will take appropriate action against employers who ill-treat their migrant workers or migrant domestic workers. If convicted, employers may be fined, jailed, or both. column4: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me
column5: What actions can the Ministry of Manpower take against employers who ill-treat their migrant workers or migrant domestic workers?
column6:
The Ministry of Manpower can take the following actions against employers who ill-treat their migrant workers or migrant domestic workers:

1. Fine the employer.
2. Jail the employer.
3. Impose both a fine and jail sentence on the employer.
4. Ban the employer from hiring foreign employees.

Please note that these actions are taken if the employer is convicted of ill-treatment.

Document Excerpt: 
31 Aug 2022): "Ensure that those who can’t cope can get help early" Support networks for domestic helpers strengthened over the years - The Straits Times, 5 Sep 2022 We thank Mr Mohamad Farid Harunal Rashid for his letter, “Ensure that maids who can’t cope can get help early” (Aug 31). The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) does not condone acts of ill-treatment by or to migrant domestic workers (MDWs). MOM has strengthened support networks for MDWs over the years. Since April 2021, we have started house visits to engage some MDWs and their employers directly. Our officers are trained to look out for indicators of stress and discuss any issues raised with employers so that they can be adequately addressed. Together with the Centre for Domestic Employees (CDE) under the National Trades Union Congress, MOM has launched two CDEConnect centres. The centres provide convenience for MDWs and their employers to walk in and seek advice on employment issues. The centres conduct compulsory interviews for all first-time MDWs to ensure they adapt well to their new role. In addition, within three months of the MDW’s placement, employment agencies must conduct a post-placement check.
', metadata={'result_id': '2bc82f2f-7845-4df4-85dc-e6b96889ee25-8b28fbf7-dab0-438a-a1b7-d96a01924954', 'document_id': 'https://www.mom.gov.sg/newsroom/press-replies/2022/0905-support-network-for-migrant-domestic-workers-strengthened-over-the-years', 'source': 'https://www.mom.gov.sg/newsroom/press-replies/2022/0905-support-network-for-migrant-domestic-workers-strengthened-over-the-years', 'title': 'Support network for migrant domestic workers strengthened over the years', 'excerpt': '31 Aug 2022): "Ensure that those who can’t cope can get help early" Support networks for domestic helpers strengthened over the years - The Straits Times, 5 Sep 2022 We thank Mr Mohamad Farid Harunal Rashid for his letter, “Ensure that maids who can’t cope can get help early” (Aug 31). The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) does not condone acts of ill-treatment by or to migrant domestic workers (MDWs). MOM has strengthened support networks for MDWs over the years. Our officers are trained to look out for indicators of stress and discuss any issues raised with employers so that they can be adequately addressed. Together with the Centre for Domestic Employees (CDE) under the National Trades Union Congress, MOM has launched two CDEConnect centres. The centres provide convenience for MDWs and their employers to walk in and seek advice on employment issues. The centres conduct compulsory interviews for all first-time MDWs to ensure they adapt well to their new role. In addition, within three months of the MDW’s placement, employment agencies must conduct a post-placement check.', 'document_attributes': {'_data_source_id': 'c3bf07c2-4275-4309-af7d-9be0ad363873', '_source_uri': 'https://www.mom.gov.sg/newsroom/press-replies/2022/0905-support-network-for-migrant-domestic-workers-strengthened-over-the-years'}}), Document(page_content='Document Title: Speech by Minister of State for Manpower, Ms Gan Siow Huang, for FAST Hub’s Official Opening and FAST’s Annual Migrant Domestic Worker (MDW) and Employer Appreciation Day
Document Excerpt: 
This will allow our migrant domestic workers to rest and recharge, and form networks of support outside the household. We hope that employers and their domestic workers can start early conversations to reach a mutual agreement on the rest day arrangement. Whole-of-Society Effort 4. Let me now touch on our whole-of-society efforts to support and care for our migrant domestic workers. The Ministry of Manpower works with our partners, such as Non-Governmental Organisations and community organisations, to strengthen support measures for our domestic workers. 5. One example is the “Care Sisters” group, where migrant domestic workers are empowered and trained to provide mental well-being support to fellow domestic workers who may be facing issues. A joint collaboration between MOM, FAST and other community partners such as the Alliance of Domestic Employee Outreach, Caring for Life and Healthserve, the “Care Sisters” group was formed earlier this year. One of these Care Sisters is Crisanta. Whenever her friends confide in her, she applies what she learns from her Psychological First Aid training. She gives useful tips to help her friends better reconcile their emotions. It also assures her friends that a trained listening ear is just a call or text away. This is the type of peer support network we aim to grow, and we hope more migrant domestic workers will join us as Care Sisters.
', metadata={'result_id': '2bc82f2f-7845-4df4-85dc-e6b96889ee25-b1500c9d-5402-467a-a1db-76c50321c13d', 'document_id': 'https://www.mom.gov.sg/newsroom/speeches/2022/1120-speech-by-minister-of-state-for-manpower-at-the-official-opening-of-fast-hub', 'source': 'https://www.mom.gov.sg/newsroom/speeches/2022/1120-speech-by-minister-of-state-for-manpower-at-the-official-opening-of-fast-hub', 'title': 'Speech by Minister of State for Manpower, Ms Gan Siow Huang, for FAST Hub’s Official Opening and FAST’s Annual Migrant Domestic Worker (MDW) and Employer Appreciation Day', 'excerpt': 'This will allow our migrant domestic workers to rest and recharge, and form networks of support outside the household. [('As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me', "I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing abuse from your employer. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being. In Singapore, ill-treatment of a foreign employee, including mental and emotional abuse, is taken seriously by the Ministry of Manpower (MOM). MOM will take appropriate action against employers who ill-treat their migrant workers or migrant domestic workers. If convicted, employers may be fined, jailed, or both. You can report suspected abuse cases to MOM at 6438 5122 or the Police at 1800-255 0000. Remember, your safety is important, and there are resources available to help you."), ('As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me', 'The Ministry of Manpower can take the following actions against employers who ill-treat their migrant workers or migrant domestic workers:

1. Fine the employer.
2. Jail the employer.
3. Impose both a fine and jail sentence on the employer.
4. Ban the employer from hiring foreign employees.

Please note that these actions are taken if the employer is convicted of ill-treatment.')]

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer pinch me
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, My employer pinch me
column6: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing this situation. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being. If you feel comfortable, you should try to communicate with your employer about the issue and express how their actions are affecting you. If the situation does not improve or if you feel unsafe, you can reach out to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) or the police for assistance. They can help investigate the matter and ensure your rights are protected. Remember, it's important to seek help and support when facing such situations.

[Document(page_content="Document Title: Temporary hiring suspension protects domestic worker and employer
Document Excerpt: 
My mum has advanced dementia and it is my wish that she lives with me and my family in the comfort of our home. Mum joined me from Penang when I gave birth to my first child in Singapore, and she stayed on thereafter to continue taking care of all of us. After years of slogging for us, it is our turn to take care of her. She has been receiving regular medical care, but in recent years, she has been increasingly exhibiting some offensive behaviour like pinching, beating, kicking and pushing away anyone who attends to her, including myself, as she does not recognise any of us now. Previous helpers, having had some training, grew into the task of taking care of her and had been able to manage her. My husband and I took in a new helper, M.E., in April, when my last helper completed her term. During the interview session, we highlighted Mum's offensive behaviour owing to advanced dementia to all the candidates. M.E. stood out among all as she showed passion and tenacity, plus she had prior experience.

With the help of the maid agency which found her and brought her back from the Indonesian Embassy, we talked to her to understand why she ran away and I said I would put in more effort to help. We also reminded her of the importance of speaking up whenever she had problems. Another six weeks passed and with more effort put in to help her with my mum, it seemed that our partnership was working out well. I observed that my mum would pinch M.E. during bath or diaper-changing sessions, but M.E. would say: "It's okay, Ma'am." I too have suffered my share of bruises. On July 27, M.E. I observed that my mum would pinch M.E. during bath or diaper-changing sessions, but M.E. would say: "It's okay, Ma'am." I too have suffered my share of bruises. On July 27, M.E. went missing again. This time, the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) got involved and the police were called in to investigate. M.E. packed up and left, and I received a note from MOM that said I would not be able to employ another helper during the investigations. All the required documentation, including a doctor's report, as well as appeal letters have already been forwarded to the relevant agencies. went missing again. All the required documentation, including a doctor's report, as well as appeal letters have already been forwarded to the relevant agencies. column4: As a migrant domestic worker, what should I do
column5: What steps should I take as a migrant domestic worker if my employer pinches me?
column6:
If your employer pinches you, it is important to take the following steps as a migrant domestic worker:

1. Ensure your safety: If you feel unsafe or threatened by your employer's actions, prioritize your safety. Remove yourself from the situation if possible and find a safe space.

2. Document the incidents: Keep a record of each instance when your employer pinches you. Note down the date, time, and details of the incident. This documentation can be useful if you need to report the abuse later.

3. Speak up: It is important to communicate with your employer about their behavior. Calmly and assertively express your concerns and let them know that their actions are not acceptable. They may not be aware of the impact their behavior is having on you.

4. Seek support: Reach out to someone you trust, such as a friend, family member, or fellow domestic worker, and share your experience. They can provide emotional support and guidance on how to handle the situation.

5. Report the abuse: If the pinching continues or escalates, it is crucial to report the abuse to the relevant authorities. Contact your country's embassy or consulate, local law enforcement, or the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore to seek assistance and file a complaint.

Remember, your safety and well-being are important. Do not hesitate to seek help and support if you are experiencing any form of abuse or mistreatment.

[Document(page_content="Document Title: Contracts and safety agreement for migrant domestic worker
Document Excerpt: 
Skip to main content Ministry of Manpower Homepage About us Menu Work passes Employment practices Workplace safety and health Statistics and publications eServices Calculators Forms Newsroom Search Employer's guide Home Work passesWork Permit for migrant domestic workerEmployer's guideContracts and safety agreement Select zoneAll All Newsroom Work passes and permits Workplace safety and health Employment practices eServices Forms Employment agencies Related questions Search query Clear search Search Close search PH pay, COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave Contracts and safety agreement for migrant domestic worker You are encouraged to sign an employment contract with your migrant domestic worker (MDW) and are required to sign a safety agreement with her. MDWs are not covered by the Employment Act because it is not practical to regulate specific aspects of domestic work, such as hours of work and work on public holidays. However, we encourage you to sign an employment contract with your MDW to avoid disputes. You and your MDW must also sign a safety agreement before she starts working for you. Employment contract The terms and conditions in your employment contract must be mutually agreed between you and your MDW.

Document Excerpt: 
Skip to main content Ministry of Manpower Homepage About us Menu Work passes Employment practices Workplace safety and health Statistics and publications eServices Calculators Forms Newsroom Search Work Permit for migrant worker Home Related questionsWork Permit for migrant workerWhat is the Household Services Scheme? Select zoneAll All Newsroom Work passes and permits Workplace safety and health Employment practices eServices Forms Employment agencies Related questions Search query Clear search Search Close search PH pay, COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave What is the Household Services Scheme? The Household Services Scheme (HSS) allows companies to hire more migrant workers to provide part-time domestic services, such as home cleaning, grocery shopping, car-washing and pet-sitting. Difference between engaging a migrant domestic worker and the services of an HSS company. Migrant domestic workers live with their employers, and can only work for them. Workers from HSS companies can be deployed to multiple houses on a part-time basis to provide select household services. They also do not live in the houses that they work at. Families who need household services on an ad-hoc basis can engage the service of a HSS company, instead of hiring a full-time live-in migrant domestic worker. To get part-time help with household chores You can contact any of these HSS companies. Companies keen to be part of HSS Companies providing household services can email us at mom_wpd@mom.gov.sg to be considered for the HSS.

Select zoneAll All Newsroom Work passes and permits Workplace safety and health Employment practices eServices Forms Employment agencies Related questions Search query Clear search Search Close search PH pay, COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave What is the Household Services Scheme? The Household Services Scheme (HSS) allows companies to hire more migrant workers to provide part-time domestic services, such as home cleaning, grocery shopping, car-washing and pet-sitting. Difference between engaging a migrant domestic worker and the services of an HSS company. Migrant domestic workers live with their employers, and can only work for them. \xa0 Workers from HSS companies can be deployed to multiple houses on a part-time basis to provide select household services. They also do not live in the houses that they work at. Families who need household services on an ad-hoc basis can engage the service of a HSS company, instead of hiring a full-time live-in migrant domestic worker. To get part-time help with household chores You can contact any of these HSS companies. For Employer of Migrant Domestic WorkerFor Employer of Migrant Domestic Worker A Guide to Enhancing your Migrant Domestic Worker’s Mental Well-being Migrant domestic workers (MDWs) leave their families and country to work in Singapore so that they can give their loved ones a better life back home. They may feel stressed working and living in a new environment. As an employer, you can support her to settle down well and look after her well-being. Read on to learn more about stress, how you can help manage your MDW’s stress level, and the channels to seek help from! IntroductionIntroductionIntroduction 1 Information contained in this guide is accurate at the time of print. 1. What is stress? 2. What are the signs and symptoms of stress? 3. How can I help my MDW manage her stress?

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, how do I start working in singapor
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, how do I start working in singapor
column6:
To start working in Singapore as a migrant domestic worker, you will need to follow these steps:

1. Find an employer: Look for an employer who is willing to hire you as a domestic worker in Singapore. You can either find an employer directly or go through an employment agency.

2. Sign an employment contract: It is encouraged for you and your employer to sign an employment contract that outlines the terms and conditions of your employment. This contract should cover aspects such as salary, rest days, notice periods, and compensation.

3. Sign a safety agreement: Before you start working for your employer, both you and your employer must sign a safety agreement. This agreement ensures that both parties understand and agree to follow safety protocols while you are working.

4. Obtain necessary documents: Your employer will need to log in to the FDW eService to download the In-Principle Approval (IPA) and declaration form. The IPA is a document that allows you to work in Singapore, and the declaration form needs to be signed by both you and your employer.

5. Buy a security bond and insurance: Your employer will need to buy a security bond and a medical and personal accident insurance for you. These are important for your protection and well-being while working in Singapore.

6. Get the permit issued: Your employer should contact your current employer to arrange the date for your transfer. On the agreed transfer date, your employer should use the FDW eService to get the new Work Permit issued and upload the signed declaration form. You will receive a Temporary Work Permit, which you should keep with you while working.

7. Start working: Once you have the Temporary Work Permit, you can start working for your new employer. Your current Work Permit will be automatically cancelled.

Remember, it is important to follow the legal procedures and requirements to ensure a smooth and legal transition to working in Singapore.
column7:
[Document(page_content='Document Title: Contracts and safety agreement for migrant domestic worker
Document Excerpt: 
PH pay, COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave Contracts and safety agreement for migrant domestic worker You are encouraged to sign an employment contract with your migrant domestic worker (MDW) and are required to sign a safety agreement with her. MDWs are not covered by the Employment Act because it is not practical to regulate specific aspects of domestic work, such as hours of work and work on public holidays. However, we encourage you to sign an employment contract with your MDW to avoid disputes. You and your MDW must also sign a safety agreement before she starts working for you. Employment contract The terms and conditions in your employment contract must be mutually agreed between you and your MDW. As an employer, you are encouraged to cover all of the following: Salary Placement loan Number of rest days per month Compensation in lieu of rest day Notice period Compensation in lieu of termination notice You can get your employment agency to draft an employment contract for you and your MDW. Terminating an employment contract Early termination is allowed to maintain flexibility for you and your MDW, as circumstances may change.

myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave Migrant Domestic Worker interviews 17 February 2023 We refer to Mr Lim’s letter on interviews with first-time migrant domestic workers (MDWs) (“人力部应考虑个别家庭难处”, 13 February). The Centre for Domestic Employees (CDE) has been conducting these interviews, on behalf of the Ministry of Manpower, to ensure that first-time MDWs are adapting well to their new working and living environments. During the interviews, the MDWs are also educated on various aspects of working in Singapore, such as safe practices while doing household chores. We understand that not all employers – such as those with constant caregiving needs - are able to send their MDWs to the interviews. In such circumstances, employers may request for alternative interview arrangements. We have reached out to Mr Lim to offer our assistance on this matter. Joann Tan Director, Engagement Foreign Manpower Management Division Ministry of Manpower _____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ Call for MOM to provide flexibility in implementation of mandatory interviews with first time-MDWs for families with constant caregiving needs - Lianhe Zaobao, 13 February I just reached an agreement with my MDW on the mandatory monthly rest day arrangement.

column3:
[Document(page_content='Document Title: Does ill-treatment of a foreign employee include mental or emotional abuse?
Document Excerpt: 
Select zoneAll All Newsroom Work passes and permits Workplace safety and health Employment practices eServices Forms Employment agencies Related questions Search query Clear search Search Close search PH pay, COMPASS, Primary Care Plan, myMOM Portal, paying salary, annual leave Does ill-treatment of a foreign employee include mental or emotional abuse? A foreign employee is ill-treated if the employer neglects their well-being. Other than physical and sexual abuse, this also include mental and emotional abuse. All employers must treat your foreign employees with care and respect. MOM will take appropriate action against employers who ill-treat their migrant workers or migrant domestic workers. If convicted, employers may be fined, jailed, or both. You may also be banned from hiring foreign employees. Last Updated: 4 October 2021 Information and Services Ministry of Manpower Social media About us Careers Feedback Share your views @ Reach Ministry of Manpower Facebook page Ministry of Manpower LinkedIn page Ministry of Manpower Telegram Ministry of Manpower youtube channel Report vulnerability Privacy Terms of use Legislation Sitemap Contact us Supported browsers © 2023 Government of Singapore

column4:
[('As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me', "I'm sorry to hear that you're facing such a difficult situation. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being. If you believe you are being abused by your employer, it is crucial to seek help and report the abuse to the appropriate authorities. You can reach out to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore for assistance and guidance. They have resources and support available for migrant domestic workers who are facing abuse. Remember, your safety is important, and there are people who can help you."), ('As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me', 'If you believe you are being abused by your employer as a migrant domestic worker, it is important to take action to protect yourself. Here are the steps you can take:

1. Reach out for help: Contact a trusted friend, family member, or fellow domestic worker who can provide support and guidance. You can also seek assistance from organizations that specialize in supporting migrant domestic workers, such as NGOs or helplines.

2. Document incidents: Keep a record of any incidents of abuse, including dates, times, and descriptions of what occurred. This documentation can be helpful if you decide to report the abuse later.

3. Report the abuse: You can report the abuse to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore. They take ill-treatment of foreign employees seriously and will investigate the matter. You can contact MOM through their website or hotline to make a report.

4. Seek medical help if needed: If you have sustained any physical injuries as a result of the abuse, seek medical attention immediately. Your health and well-being should be a priority.

Remember, it is important to take action and seek help if you are being abused. You have the right to be treated with care and respect.')]
As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me
column5: What steps can I take if I believe I am being abused by my employer as a migrant domestic worker?
column6:
If you believe you are being abused by your employer as a migrant domestic worker, there are steps you can take to seek help and protect yourself. Here are some actions you can consider:

1. Reach out to a trusted person: Talk to someone you trust, such as a friend, family member, or fellow domestic worker, about your situation. They may be able to provide support and guidance.

2. Contact your embassy or consulate: Reach out to your country's embassy or consulate in Singapore. They can provide assistance and advice on how to handle your situation.

3. Seek help from organizations: There are organizations in Singapore that specifically support migrant domestic workers. You can contact them for help and advice. Some examples include the Humanitarian Organization for Migration Economics (HOME) and the Centre for Domestic Employees (CDE).

4. Report the abuse to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM): You can file a complaint with MOM if you are experiencing abuse. They take such cases seriously and will investigate the matter. You can contact MOM directly or seek assistance from the organizations mentioned above.

Remember, it is important to prioritize your safety and well-being. Do not hesitate to seek help and support when needed.

column7:
[Document(page_content="Document Title: Response to Adjournment Motion on Role of Migrant Domestic Workers in Singapore's Caregiving Landscape
Document Excerpt: 
Some MDWs were found in the course of Police investigations to have made false allegations against their employers. The Police and MOM will not hesitate to take firm action against such MDWs. a. Over the past two years, Police investigated and issued warnings to 17 MDWs for providing false information against the household or employer. Of these, 13 were blacklisted and the remaining 4 are pending a review of case facts. b. I would like to share a story about an MDW who made a police report, claiming that her employer’s wife physically abused her by slapping her limbs over a period of seven months. Over the past two years, Police investigated and issued warnings to 17 MDWs for providing false information against the household or employer. Of these, 13 were blacklisted and the remaining 4 are pending a review of case facts. b. I would like to share a story about an MDW who made a police report, claiming that her employer’s wife physically abused her by slapping her limbs over a period of seven months. Upon thorough investigation by the police, the MDW admitted to providing false information against her employer in a bid to end her employment. She was charged under the Penal Code for providing false information, convicted and sentenced to four weeks’ imprisonment. She was also repatriated and banned from working in Singapore. 16. We encourage employers and MDWs to maintain open communication with one another, discuss their concerns and resolve disputes amicably. Fostering a sense of mutual trust and respect can help prevent misunderstandings from occurring. MOM’s vision of fairness towards both ERs and MDW 17.

column8: [('As a migrant domestic worker, My employer abused me', "I'm sorry to hear that you're facing such a difficult situation. It's important to prioritize your safety and well-being. If you believe you are being abused by your employer, it is crucial to seek help and report the abuse to the appropriate authorities. You can reach out to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore for assistance and guidance. They have resources and support available for migrant domestic workers who are facing abuse. Remember, your safety is important, and there are people who can help you.")]

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, how can i send money home
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, how can i send money home
column6:
You can send money home using e-remittance. E-remittance is an easy and convenient way to send money back to your family overseas online. All you need is a bank account and a mobile phone. Remember to never share your personal banking ID, password/PIN, and One-Time Passwords (OTP) with anyone. Only share your work permit photo or do a video call for verification when you have confirmed that the Ministry of Manpower agent is licensed. Here are the steps to e-remit safely:
1. Make sure you have a bank account.
2. Find a licensed remittance company from the Monetary Authority of Singapore's website (https://eservices.mas.gov.sg/fid).
3. Prepare the details needed for your e-remittance.

If you have any further questions or need assistance, feel free to ask.

ISSUE 28/ JUNE 2022 INFORM MINISTRY OF MANPOWER A Ministry of Ministry of Manpower (MOM) publication for Migrant Domestic Workers (MDWs) in Singapore Perform domestic work for your official employer only 01 DO The name of your official employer is stated in your work permit card. It is an offence if you work for someone else; or perform non-domestic work for your official employer. You will be fined or jailed for working illegally. You will also be sent back home and cannot enter or work in Singapore anymore. Why not spend your rest day meaningfully by taking up a course or becoming a volunteer? Read on to find out more. Scan here to find out the list of useful contacts For more information related to working in Singapore, visit here: Publications and resources Singapore Ministry of Manpower GO.gov.sg (www.mom.gov.sg/ I Facebook fdw-employer-resources) Subscribe to MOM Facebook today! 1 Are you communicating well with your employer?

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, im sick
column5: What should I do if I am sick as a migrant domestic worker?
column6: I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling sick. As a chatbot, I'm unable to provide medical advice. It's important for you to seek medical attention if you're feeling unwell. You can contact the MDW Helpline for assistance at 1800 339 5505. They may be able to provide you with further guidance and support.

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, can i work part time
column5: As a migrant domestic worker, can i work part time
column6: According to the document, migrant domestic workers are not allowed to work part-time, be it full-time or part-time. Your off days should be used to rest, recharge and enjoy time out with your family or friends.

column8: [('As a migrant domestic worker, can i work part time', 'According to the document, migrant domestic workers are not allowed to work part-time, be it full-time or part-time. Your off days should be used to rest, recharge and enjoy time out with your family or friends.')]

column4: As a migrant domestic worker, being abused
column5: What should I do if I am being abused as a migrant domestic worker?
column6: If you have been abused or ill-treated by your employer, you should call the Police (999) for help immediately. You can also fill up and mail the feedback form given out during the Settling-In- Programme to MOM. Additionally, seek help from your neighbours, fellow MDWs or any member of the public. Remember to protect yourself from abuse by being honest and always telling the truth.

I would not pretend to understand because I may end up making more mistakes. Q: Do you have any tips to share with other MDWs? A: Communication is the key to maintaining a good relationship with your employer. 1 Pay attention and listen carefully to your employer's instructions. Write them down so that you can remember them easily. 2 Check in and discuss with your employer on how he/she feels about your work performance. 3 Be honest and always tell the truth. 4 Be humble and respectful towards your employer. 3 Protect Yourself from Abuse! 1 If you have been abused or 2 If you are unable to make phone ill-treated by your employer, you calls from your employer's house or should call the Police (999) for your mobile phone, you can: help immediately. column4: As a migrant domestic worker, how to seek help
column5: How can a migrant domestic worker seek help if they are being abused or ill-treated by their employer?
column6:
As a migrant domestic worker, you can seek help by:
- Calling the MDW Helpline for MDWs in distress at 1800 339 5505
- Calling the Singapore Police Force at 999 if you are in danger
- Filling up and mailing the feedback form given out during the Settling-In-Programme to MOM
- Writing a simple note including your name, Work Permit number and home address, and passing it to your neighbour or any member of the public so that they can help you
- Seeking help from your neighbours, fellow MDWs, or any member of the public
- Calling your employment agency or the Ministry of Manpower at 1800 339 5505 if your employer does not follow any of the work permit conditions
If you have been abused or ill-treated by your employer, you should call the Police (999) for help immediately.

A: Communication is the key to maintaining a good relationship with your employer. 1 Pay attention and listen carefully to your employer's instructions. Write them down so that you can remember them easily. 2 Check in and discuss with your employer on how he/she feels about your work performance. 3 Be honest and always tell the truth. 4 Be humble and respectful towards your employer. 3 Protect Yourself from Abuse! 1 If you have been abused or 2 If you are unable to make phone ill-treated by your employer, you calls from your employer's house or should call the Police (999) for your mobile phone, you can: help immediately. Remember THE WORK PERMIT CONDITIONS SAFETY AT HOME 13 14 IF YOUR EMPLOYER DOES NOT FOLLOW ANY OF THE WORK PERMIT CONDITIONS, YOU SHOULD CALL: • Your employment agency • Ministry of Manpower (1800 339 5505) IF YOUR EMPLOYER MISTREATS YOU WITH ABUSE OR THREATS, YOU SHOULD CALL: • Police (999) If you are unable to make phone calls from your employer’s house, there are other ways to seek help: WORKING IN A HIGH-RISE APARTMENT Most Singaporean families live in high-rise homes such as Housing Development Board (HDB) flats, apartments or condominiums. (1800 339 5505) IF YOUR EMPLOYER MISTREATS YOU WITH ABUSE OR THREATS, YOU SHOULD CALL: • Police (999) If you are unable to make phone calls from your employer’s house, there are other ways to seek help: WORKING IN A HIGH-RISE APARTMENT Most Singaporean families live in high-rise homes such as Housing Development Board (HDB) flats, apartments or condominiums. If your employer lives in a high-rise building, the risk of falling from heights is real, especially if you are cleaning windows and hanging laundry. It is therefore important that you follow these safety guidelines: When hanging laundry DOs • Hang heavier clothes closer to the bracket, and lighter clothes at the far end of the pole. • Keep your feet firmly on the ground.
